MATH101.title: Calculus I
MATH101.description: Introduction to limits, continuity, differentiation, and applications of derivatives. Fundamental theorem of calculus and basic integration.

lessons: Rolle's Theorem and Mean Value Theorem

MATH101.mastery_rubric: To pass, students must demonstrate proficiency in calculating limits, derivatives, and basic integrals. A strong understanding of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus and applications of derivatives (e.g., optimization) is required. Final course grade must be 70% or higher, with at least 60% on the final exam.

MATH102.title: Calculus II
MATH102.description: Techniques of integration, applications of integration, sequences and series, parametric equations, and polar coordinates.

lessons: Area and Arc Length in Polar Coordinates

MATH102.mastery_rubric: To pass, students must master various integration techniques and their applications, especially in calculating volumes and arc lengths. A solid grasp of convergence tests for sequences and series, and the ability to work with power, Taylor, and Maclaurin series, is essential. Final course grade must be 70% or higher, with at least 60% on the final exam.

MATH201.title: Multivariable Calculus
MATH201.description: Functions of several variables, partial derivatives, multiple integrals, vector calculus, Green's, Stokes', and Divergence Theorems.

modules.module_title: Vectors and the Geometry of Space

lessons: Derivatives and Integrals of Vector Functions
Directional Derivatives and the Gradient Vector
Change of Variables in Multiple Integrals

MATH201.mastery_rubric: To pass, students must demonstrate a comprehensive understanding of multivariable functions, partial differentiation, and multiple integration. Proficiency in vector calculus, including line and surface integrals, and the application of Green's, Stokes', and Divergence Theorems is required. Final course grade must be 70% or higher, with at least 60% on the final exam.

MATH202.title: Differential Equations
MATH202.description: First-order equations, second-order linear equations, series solutions, Laplace transforms, and systems of differential equations.

lessons: Homogeneous Linear Equations with Constant Coefficients

modules.module_title: Systems of Linear First-Order Differential Equations

MATH202.mastery_rubric: To pass, students must be able to solve various types of first- and second-order differential equations, apply Laplace transforms, and find series solutions. A clear understanding of modeling real-world phenomena with differential equations is crucial. Final course grade must be 70% or higher, with at least 60% on the final exam.

MATH203.title: Linear Algebra
MATH203.description: Systems of linear equations, matrices, determinants, vector spaces, linear transformations, eigenvalues, and eigenvectors.

modules.module_title: Systems of Linear Equations and Matrices
lessons: Introduction to Systems of Linear Equations
Elementary Matrices and a Method for Finding A⁻¹
Row Space, Column Space, and Null Space

MATH203.mastery_rubric: To pass, students must demonstrate strong computational skills in solving linear systems, matrix operations, and finding determinants. A conceptual understanding of vector spaces, linear transformations, eigenvalues, and eigenvectors is crucial. Final course grade must be 70% or higher, with at least 60% on the final exam.

MATH301.title: Real Analysis I
MATH301.description: Rigorous treatment of real numbers, sequences, series, limits, continuity, differentiation, and Riemann integration.

lessons: Archimedean Property and Density of Rationals/Irrationals

modules.module_title: Sequences and Series of Real Numbers

MATH301.mastery_rubric: To pass, students must demonstrate a rigorous understanding of the foundational concepts of real analysis, including epsilon-delta proofs for limits and continuity, properties of sequences and series, and the theory of differentiation and Riemann integration. The ability to construct formal mathematical proofs is paramount. Final course grade must be 70% or higher, with at least 60% on the final exam.

MATH302.title: Abstract Algebra I
MATH302.description: Introduction to group theory: groups, subgroups, normal subgroups, homomorphisms, and quotient groups.

modules.module_title: Direct Products and Finitely Generated Abelian Groups
lessons: Fundamental Theorem of Finitely Generated Abelian Groups

MATH302.mastery_rubric: To pass, students must demonstrate a conceptual understanding of groups, subgroups, and homomorphisms, and be able to construct proofs related to these structures. Proficiency in working with cosets, normal subgroups, and factor groups is essential. Final course grade must be 70% or higher, with at least 60% on the final exam.

MATH303.title: Complex Analysis
MATH303.description: Complex numbers, analytic functions, Cauchy-Riemann equations, complex integration, power series, and residue theory.

lessons: Complex Numbers and the Complex Plane

MATH303.mastery_rubric: To pass, students must demonstrate a strong understanding of complex numbers, analytic functions, and the Cauchy-Riemann equations. Proficiency in complex integration, residue theory, and applications to evaluating real integrals is required. Final course grade must be 70% or higher, with at least 60% on the final exam.

MATH304.title: Introduction to Topology
MATH304.description: Foundations of point-set topology: topological spaces, continuous functions, compactness, connectedness, and separation axioms.

lessons: Metric Spaces and Topologies Induced by Metrics
Urysohn's Lemma and Tietze Extension Theorem

MATH304.mastery_rubric: To pass, students must develop a rigorous understanding of topological spaces, continuous functions, and homeomorphisms. The ability to prove properties related to compactness, connectedness, and the various separation axioms is crucial. Final course grade must be 70% or higher, with at least 60% on the final exam.

MATH350.title: Numerical Analysis I
MATH350.description: Introduction to numerical methods: error analysis, solving nonlinear equations, interpolation, numerical differentiation, and integration.

modules.module_title: Solutions of Equations in One Variable
Direct Methods for Solving Linear Systems

MATH350.mastery_rubric: To pass, students must understand fundamental numerical methods for solving mathematical problems, including error analysis. Proficiency in implementing and analyzing algorithms for root finding, interpolation, differentiation, and integration is required. The ability to analyze the stability and convergence of numerical schemes is crucial. Final course grade must be 70% or higher, with at least 60% on the final exam or project.

MATH351.title: Numerical Analysis II
MATH351.description: Advanced numerical methods: iterative methods for linear systems, eigenvalue problems, and numerical solutions of ordinary and partial differential equations.

modules.module_title: Iterative Techniques for Solving Linear Systems
Numerical Solutions of Ordinary Differential Equations
Numerical Solutions of Partial Differential Equations
lessons: Finite Difference Method for Laplace Equation
Finite Difference Method for Heat Equation
Finite Difference Method for Wave Equation

MATH351.mastery_rubric: To pass, students must demonstrate proficiency in advanced numerical techniques for solving complex mathematical problems, including iterative methods for linear systems, eigenvalue computation, and the numerical solution of differential equations. The ability to select appropriate methods and analyze their convergence and error properties is crucial. Final course grade must be 70% or higher, with at least 60% on the final exam or project.

MATH401.title: Introduction to Graduate Mathematics
MATH401.description: A capstone course preparing students for graduate-level studies, covering advanced topics and interconnections across pure and applied mathematics.

lessons: Introduction to Ring and Field Theory

modules.module_title: Introduction to Manifolds and Differential Geometry

lessons: Applications of PDEs in Physics and Engineering

MATH401.mastery_rubric: To pass, students must demonstrate a broad and deep understanding of advanced mathematical concepts and their interconnections, suitable for graduate studies. The ability to synthesize knowledge from various branches of mathematics and engage with abstract theoretical arguments is essential. Final course grade must be 70% or higher, with at least 60% on the final exam.

MATH410.title: Abstract Algebra II (Ring Theory)
MATH410.description: Advanced topics in ring theory: rings, ideals, quotient rings, integral domains, unique factorization domains, and field extensions.

lessons: Homomorphisms and Isomorphism Theorems for Rings

MATH410.mastery_rubric: To pass, students must demonstrate a thorough understanding of ring theory, including ideals, factor rings, and polynomial rings. The ability to construct proofs related to ring properties, irreducibility, and field extensions is crucial. Final course grade must be 70% or higher, with at least 60% on the final exam.

MATH411.title: Abstract Algebra III (Galois Theory)
MATH411.description: Further exploration of field theory, including advanced topics in Galois theory and its applications to polynomial solvability.

lessons: The Fundamental Theorem of Galois Theory

MATH411.mastery_rubric: To pass, students must demonstrate a deep understanding of Galois theory, including its fundamental theorem and applications to the solvability of polynomials. The ability to compute Galois groups and apply the theory to specific examples is essential. Final course grade must be 70% or higher, with at least 60% on the final exam.

MATH412.title: Algebraic Number Theory
MATH412.description: Introduction to algebraic number theory, including algebraic integers, number fields, unique factorization of ideals, and Dirichlet's Unit Theorem.
MATH412.mastery_rubric: To pass, students must demonstrate a foundational understanding of algebraic number theory, including algebraic integers, number fields, and the unique factorization of ideals. The ability to work with class groups and apply Dirichlet's Unit Theorem is crucial. Final course grade must be 70% or higher, with at least 60% on the final exam.

MATH420.title: Real Analysis II (Measure Theory)
MATH420.description: Advanced topics in measure theory and Lebesgue integration: Lebesgue measure, measurable functions, Lp spaces, and convergence theorems.
MATH420.mastery_rubric: To pass, students must demonstrate a rigorous understanding of measure theory and Lebesgue integration, including the construction of Lebesgue measure and integral, and the various convergence theorems. The ability to work with Lp spaces and apply the theoretical concepts to advanced problems is essential. Final course grade must be 70% or higher, with at least 60% on the final exam.

MATH421.title: Functional Analysis I
MATH421.description: Introduction to functional analysis: normed spaces, Banach spaces, Hilbert spaces, and fundamental theorems.
MATH421.mastery_rubric: To pass, students must demonstrate a strong understanding of normed spaces, Banach spaces, and Hilbert spaces, along with linear operators and functionals. The ability to apply the fundamental theorems of functional analysis (Hahn-Banach, Uniform Boundedness, Open Mapping, Closed Graph) is crucial. Final course grade must be 70% or higher, with at least 60% on the final exam.

MATH430.title: Differential Geometry I
MATH430.description: Theory of curves and surfaces in three-dimensional Euclidean space, including curvature, torsion, and fundamental forms.
MATH430.mastery_rubric: To pass, students must demonstrate a firm grasp of the differential geometry of curves and surfaces, including the calculation of curvature, torsion, and fundamental forms. The ability to apply the Frenet-Serret formulas and understand Gaussian and Mean curvature is essential. Final course grade must be 70% or higher, with at least 60% on the final exam.

MATH431.title: Introduction to Algebraic Topology
MATH431.description: Fundamental group, covering spaces, and an introduction to homology theory.

lessons: Covering Spaces and the Fundamental Group

MATH431.mastery_rubric: To pass, students must demonstrate a conceptual understanding of homotopy, the fundamental group, and covering spaces. The ability to compute the fundamental group for basic spaces and an introduction to the principles of homology theory are required. Final course grade must be 70% or higher, with at least 60% on the final exam.

MATH498.title: Senior Capstone Project in Mathematics
MATH498.description: An independent research project or advanced seminar culminating in a written report and presentation.

lessons: Delivering a Research Presentation and Defense

MATH498.mastery_rubric: To pass, students must successfully complete an independent research project or an in-depth analysis of an advanced mathematical topic. This includes formulating a clear research question, conducting thorough research, applying appropriate mathematical methods, and presenting findings in a well-structured written report and an oral defense. The project must demonstrate a high level of mathematical maturity and independent thought. A panel of faculty will evaluate the project and presentation.

STAT301.title: Probability Theory
STAT301.description: Axioms of probability, conditional probability, random variables, probability distributions, expectation, variance, and limit theorems.

lessons: Random Variables and Probability Mass Functions
Expected Value of Discrete Random Variables
Expected Value of Continuous Random Variables

STAT301.mastery_rubric: To pass, students must demonstrate a strong understanding of fundamental probability concepts, including conditional probability, random variables, and various probability distributions (discrete and continuous). Proficiency in calculating expected values, variances, and applying limit theorems is essential. Final course grade must be 70% or higher, with at least 60% on the final exam.

STAT302.title: Mathematical Statistics
STAT302.description: Introduction to statistical inference: point estimation, interval estimation, hypothesis testing, and likelihood methods.

lessons: Sampling Distributions of the Mean and Proportion
Type I and Type II Errors

STAT302.mastery_rubric: To pass, students must demonstrate a strong understanding of statistical inference, including point and interval estimation, and various hypothesis testing procedures. Proficiency in applying likelihood methods and interpreting statistical results is essential. Final course grade must be 70% or higher, with at least 60% on the final exam.

MATH204.title: Discrete Mathematics
MATH204.description: Introduction to fundamental concepts of discrete mathematics, including logic, set theory, proof techniques, combinatorics, graph theory, and algorithms.
MATH204.mastery_rubric: To pass, students must demonstrate a clear understanding of logical reasoning, set theory, and basic proof techniques. Proficiency in combinatorial counting, fundamental graph theory concepts, and algorithmic analysis is required. Final course grade must be 70% or higher, with at least 60% on the final exam.

MATH402.title: Numerical Linear Algebra
MATH402.description: Numerical methods for solving problems in linear algebra, including systems of equations, least squares, eigenvalue problems, and singular value decomposition.
MATH402.mastery_rubric: To pass, students must master numerical techniques for linear algebraic problems, including direct and iterative methods for linear systems, and algorithms for eigenvalue problems. The ability to analyze stability, accuracy, and efficiency of these methods is crucial. Final course grade must be 70% or higher, with at least 60% on the final exam or project.

MATH403.title: Partial Differential Equations
MATH403.description: Introduction to partial differential equations: classification, method of characteristics, separation of variables, Fourier series, and applications.
MATH403.mastery_rubric: To pass, students must understand the classification of PDEs and master various analytical solution techniques, especially separation of variables and Fourier series. The ability to apply PDEs to model physical phenomena and interpret solutions is essential. Final course grade must be 70% or higher, with at least 60% on the final exam.

STAT401.title: Regression Analysis
STAT401.description: Advanced topics in linear regression, including multiple regression, model selection, diagnostics, and an introduction to generalized linear models.
STAT401.mastery_rubric: To pass, students must demonstrate mastery of multiple linear regression, including model building, diagnostics, and interpretation. Proficiency in model selection techniques and an understanding of generalized linear models are required. The ability to apply regression methods to real-world data using statistical software is crucial. Final course grade must be 70% or higher, with at least 60% on the final exam or project.

STAT402.title: Bayesian Statistics
STAT402.description: Foundations of Bayesian inference, including Bayes' Theorem, prior and posterior distributions, Bayesian estimation, and hypothesis testing.
STAT402.mastery_rubric: To pass, students must demonstrate a strong understanding of Bayesian principles, including constructing prior and posterior distributions, and performing Bayesian estimation and hypothesis testing. Proficiency in basic computational Bayesian methods like MCMC is required. The ability to apply Bayesian inference to statistical problems is crucial. Final course grade must be 70% or higher, with at least 60% on the final exam or project.
